indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Existence de mécanismes et de procédés de planification et de gestion des risques pouvant guider des interventions sensible au genre du Gouvernement haïtien dans la livraison de logement et de services de base améliorées répondant aux priorités des habitants afin d’améliorer durablement les conditions de vie des familles dans les quartiers ciblés. 2. Nombre de nouveaux emplois et d'autres moyens de subsistance générés par le projet dans un contexte de crise ou de post-crise ventilée par sexe 3. Niveau d’accès aux services de base répondant aux priorités des habitants des quartiers ciblés 4. Niveau d’accès à des infrastructures communautaires priorisées par la communauté dans les quartiers ciblés

baseline.comment: 1. Absence de mécanismes et de procédés de planification et de gestion des risques pouvant guider des interventions sensible au genre du Gouvernement haïtien dans la livraison de logement et de services de base améliorées répondant aux priorités des habitants afin d’améliorer durablement les conditions de vie des familles dans les quartiers ciblés. 2. Perte considérable d’emplois et d'autres moyens de subsistance à cause du tremblement de terre ventilée par sexe (Réf : PDNA – 8.5% de perte d’emplois après le tremblement de terre) 3. Niveau d’accès minimal aux services de base répondant aux priorités des habitants des 8 quartiers ciblés (Les 8 quartiers ciblés) 4. Niveau d’accès minimal à des infrastructures communautaires priorisées par la communauté dans les 8 quartiers ciblés

result.title: Objective
result.description: By June 2014, Haiti has designed and started initial implementation of an integrated operational and financial framework to ensure long term sustainability of the national PA system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Area (in hectares) in the protected areas and number of APs legally included in
SNAP.

baseline.comment: There are 10 PA in Haiti, covering a total surface of 12,854 ha. But none of them are legally incorporated to the NPAS, which is not officially implemented to date.

target.comment: At the End of Project, at least the 3 major PA are legally incorporated into the NPAS, covering 10,500 ha, i.e. 86% of surfaces covered by PA in Haiti.

actual.comment:
An important effort was made by the SNAP:
(i) - 3 Priority Protected Areas Macaya Park (Park 8166 ha), La visite Park (11426 ha), Citadelle Park (2500 ha), Foret des Pins (Unit I) Park (14000 ha) and Foret des Pins (Unit II) Park (4780 ha), are legally incorporated in NPAS, they constitute the bulk of the SNAP with an area of over 22, 000 has. They were extended through presidential decrees in 2013.
(ii) - The study on the representativeness of Ecosystems SNAP is underway and the final document is scheduled for August 30, 2015.
(iii) - The continued demarcation activity at the tour with support from CIAT.
(iv) - The Macaya management plan is realized and ready to be submitted for validation.
(v) - The SNAP project works with the ANAP, the CNIGS and CIAT for the delineation of other protected areas in the country to reach the international standard. Meanwhile, final study on AP representativeness and consistency was undertaken:
bays Park (75618 ha), National Natural Parc Ile-à-Vache (11235 ha), Grosse Cayes Protected area management Habitat / Species / Aquin wet area (10974 ha), Olivier/Zanglais Protected area management Habitat / Species (7553 ha), Fonds des Cayes Protected area management Habitat / Species (2365 ha), Pointe Abacou Protected area management Habitat / Species (1840 ha), Port-Salut Protected Natural Landscape Marine and Terrestrial (1840 ha), Marie Jeanne Cave (31ha), Plaine Cahouane Protected area management Habitat /Species et associated
watershed (5940 ha)
(vi) - Besides the study, emphasis is made in the delineation of some of these protected areas. Currently the ANAP is currently working on demarcation (boundary marking) of these legally defined Pas. The Citadelle Park was created by CIAT and pursuing now working on the boundary demarcation of the Macaya PA’ including La Visite Park with the support of the SNAP project.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Rate of importance of the performance and management activities at the level of SNAP measured by the intermediary METT.

baseline.comment: Level of METT reference for the 3 protected areas was « Low » 1 (ForÃªt des Pins: 33; Macaya: 32; La Visite: 32) (less thaan 45 = Low)

target.comment: By end of Project: METT scores for the 3 PA of reference will have moved to the medium METT category (45-54= Medium)

actual.comment:
The financial strategy SNAP has been finalized and various innovative tools for
mobilizing financial resources to ensure long-term financing of SNAP have been
Identified and developed.
The capacities of National Agency of Protected Areas to manage SNAP have been further reinforced by GEF/UNDP project and other partners in the management of established protected areas. Important effort was also made on the recruitment and training of parks directors and technical park maintenance officers (surveillance staff), including elaboration of management plans in priority protected areas.
A methodological guideline for the development and management of PA planning
Has been achieved. The training modules are followed by the other partners working in Forêt des Pins and Trou Caiman, (a new protected area currently being created. It is Planned to start the construction works of three other parks management plan for 3 Baies, La Visite and Foret des Pins. The process of developing management plans is closely coordinated by the ANAP and involves the participation of local actors living in
park areas.
SNAP project has recruited consultants for the development of these plans. The management plan of Macaya Park is elaborated in cooperation with the ANAP, CIAT, UNDP, UNEP and the IDB. The management plan of La Visite will be conducted jointly with the ANAP, CIAT, the Seguin Foundation and UNDP. The management plan of the Foret des Pins is done in cooperation with ANAP, CIAT, UNDP and Helvetas Swiss Cooperation.
In collaboration with IADB and the governmental Technical Unit, Baseline studies
are conducted for socio-economic and biological data collection , essential to the achievement of the Management Plan of the Parks. The achievement of management plans of the protected areas allows programming in time and space for activities within and around the protected area. However, there is a need to further empower ANAP for ownership, development and application of these tools developed.

indicator.description: Percentage of SNAPâ€™s financial capacity increase, as measured by improvement of the average score of the 3 components of UNDPâ€™s financial score card.

actual.comment:

needs spend $ 3.5 million in year "starter" with only 3 priority parks to reach $ 7.8

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Improved PA governance system, backed by policies, regulations and competent institutions, enables more cost efficient use of funds available for PA management.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Degree of adoption/enforcement of a National PA System Policy, which 1) defines the NPAS and the ANAP; 2) clarifies the roles and responsibilities of the Ministries of Environment and Agriculture and their dependencies, 3) involves local governments and actors.

baseline.comment:
Currently, there is no official definition of the NPAS, and the ANAP is neither defined nor implemented.
The legal and institutional frameworks are not enforced.

actual.comment:
The SNAP project has supported the design and capacity building of ANAP as a legally effective Governmental agency to cope the management of increasing number of protected areas. A set of strategic documents involving policy, legal frameworks (Organic law), regulations and guidelines were developed and will be submitted officially to the Government for endorsement and legal approval for SNAP governing, management and operation nationwide. However, there are still some barriers hat need to be lifted by ANAP, such as (i) low or poor fund raising, (ii)
Demarcation of PAs (boundaries, mapping, description, etc), (iii) enforcement of regulations (access to resources and sanctions, etc..), (iv) lack of well trained professional and surveillance teams for established PAs, (v) lack of social and economic alternatives for a growing population living in and around PAs.
A 5 years Business Plan was developed and finalized as part of the development of the financial strategy. The project worked in synergy / support PARC project to provide efficient support to MoE in the development of its organic law which is an essential prerequisite for ANAP reinforcement.
The promotion of the Organic Law and the strategy organizing the management and sustainable financing mechanisms, planned is not yet conducted, as the proposed Law framework is not yet adopted.
The finalization of the website planned for this year is not yet developed is will being developed and will be likely operational before end of the project. As for the Webmaster, its creation will start in October 2015.
The elaboration and implementation of database on Pas and Biodiversity is on good progress and will be finalized by August, 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Strengthened business planning and other tools for cost-effective management as measured by an increased score in the following 5 elements of Component 2 of UNDP Financial scorecard (Business planning and other tools for cost-effective management):

actual.comment:
Apart from the documents produced during the financial strategy, there is no
Significant progress made to date. The work for 2015 is being implemented just recently, due to the late validation of the Work plan and budget. The implementation of the business plans of La Visite and the Three Bays is being delayed.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. % of Protected Areas within NPAS with Management Plans, based on NPAS management plans standards

baseline.comment: 0 % (NPAS management plans standards have not been defined yet).

target.comment: 100% of all PA units within NPAS (3)

actual.comment:
A methodological guide for the development and management of PA plans has
been achieved. The Macaya management plan is under formulation and training
modules are followed by partners working in Forêt des Pins and Trou Caiman. The process of developing management plans is closely coordinated by the ANAP and involves the participation of parks teams, and local actors living in parks. Currently, the SNAP project is recruiting consultants for the development of these plans. The management plan of Macaya Park is conducted in cooperation with the ANAP, CIAT (Comité Interministériel d’Aménagement du Territoire),, UNDP, UNEP and the IADB. The management plan of La Visite is being formulated Jointly with the ANAP, CIAT, the
Seguin Foundation, a local NGO, and UNDP. The management plan of the Foret
des Pins is being made in cooperation with the ANAP, CIAT, UNDP and Helvetas
Swiss Cooperation. The elaboration of the plan for Foret des Pins is being conducted by Helvitas Swissland.
The demarcation activities of the PAs by CIAT is still on-going.
ANAP capacity building is in a good progress. The workshops on biodiversity conservation is being initiated and will be completed in August 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 5. % of PA management costs requirements met through a combination of Government (including local governments) and donor funding

baseline.comment: N/A

target.comment: At the end of the project, 85 % of the managements costs are met through a combination of Government (including local governments) and donor funding

actual.comment:
At this stage of the project, this indicator is not measurable, as we are still currently
Finalizing, thus not yet implementing the plans developed for priority protected areas in the country. These plans provide rough figures on the costs of management of the Pas, including the contribution of local and national governments as well as donor areas.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Promoted partnerships increases the social, ecological and financial sustainability of PAs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Number of PA managed under co-management agreements, between municipalities and PA operators

baseline.comment: 0 at the beginning of the project

target.comment: At least 3 major PA are co-managed at the end of the project, covering 10,400 ha (81% of PA estate).

actual.comment:
Co-management agreements have been identified as valuable tools for financing the
country's protected areas as:
Middle to reduce costs supported by the State
Mechanism of PA management in collaboration with NGOs, local associations
or private sector, such as Park Martissant co-managed by FOKAL (a national Haitian NGO under a contract ). However, there is no sharing of information on management costs. The co-management councils for Foret des Pins planned for this year is not yet operational due to the lack of designed management plan.
ANAP has organized meetings with its technical and financial partners to explore
and consider the use of the tools in some parks where partners are already active
as Macaya and La Visite, including 3 Bays’ marine park.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Development of a model for public-private concession agreements (including local actors) for provision of non-essential services and degree of its up-scaling throughout the whole PA system in priority areas for biodiversity conservation.

baseline.comment: No pilot experiences of joint work with local stakeholders for the operation of Non-essential Services and PA management;

target.comment:
By Year 3, a model generated based on 1 initial pilot demonstration;
By Year 5, the model is replicated through 2 new Agreements in PAs in other Conservation Areas; The model is fully incorporated into official NPAS policies by End of Project.

actual.comment: Activity in progress

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Number of local management committees implemented

baseline.comment: None at the beginning of the project.

target.comment: At least 3 local management committees implemented by the end of the project.

actual.comment: Activity under progress

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Diversified PA income sources increase income and reduce vulnerability to funding fluctuations

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % of PA budgets nationally coming from sources other than Government recurrent budget

baseline.comment:
85.2%
(in 2009, us$ 40,000 come from the government, and us$ 230,000 from other sources. But the NPAS is not operational, and the funds are dedicated only to PA units)

target.comment: By the end of the project, 50% of PA budgets nationally coming from sources other than Government recurrent budget

actual.comment: The existing funding for SNAP resources from the GoH contribution is estimated to 4% of financing and donors for the rest. It is recommended that in the financial strategy, the GoH increase its contribution.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: % of essential recurrent costs of 3 major PAs are covered by Government, alternative income sources and PAs\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\' own revenue generation mechanisms

baseline.comment:
ND
Annual needs not defined.
Annual income 2008 (us$)
Foret des Pins: nd
Macaya: 120,000
La Visite : 150,000

target.comment: At least 80%

actual.comment:
Recurrent costs of the Pas management were assessed. However, due to current situation of ANAP, no much progress has been made to cover a large percentage of the cost of AP budget from the government.
Projected financing needs of SNAP were produced over the period of 5 years of the plan. These needs is $ 3.5 million in year at the starting and only 3 priority parks to reach $ 7.8 million when the SNAP has 9 parks and 9.2 million when it has 12.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Diversification of revenue generation and mobilization of the NPAS and 3 major PAs in Haiti as measured through improvement in the detailed scores of the 7 elements of the component #3 (Tools and systems for revenue generation and mobilization ) of the UNDP Financial Scorecard as follows

baseline.comment:

Element 3 3/3

actual.comment:
No progress has been made in the implementation of the financial strategy of SNAP, apart from a number of documents directly related to diversification of revenue produced(see list below):
Financial Plan of the National System of Protected Areas (SNAP) and the
National Agency for Protected Areas (ANAP)
Financing of Protected Areas of Haiti: REPORT ON THE TOOLS AVAILABLE
Payments for hydrological services provided by protected areas in Haiti
Economic Evaluation of priority protected areas Haiti
Report on sustainable tourism as a tool available
These tools describe several financing mechanisms for Conservation trust funds (CTFs), payments for environmental services, carbon offsets, Compensation for loss of biodiversity, Co-Management and ecotourism. Appropriation and legal creation of ANAP are needed to achieve this result.
SNAP procured greenhouse for crop and vegetable produced, unfortunately due to lack of water source in the Project area-Foret des pins, there are not installed and no production is done. Alternative solutions are being investigated by ANAP and Agricultural department to relocate the production in another area.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To create an enabling environment for private and public investment in small hydro plants in Haiti.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) Number of new SHP projects under construction;

baseline.comment: A) No SHP currently under development;

target.comment: A) MoU signed for construction of Two (2) SHP projects;

actual.comment:
A) The procedure to hire a consultant to define the new legal framework could not be completed. The process must be restarted quickly.
The MoU allowing IPP to invest in the construction of two power plants has not been signed between the government and SOLEO Energy.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Capital secured for SHP investment

baseline.comment: (B) Private sector and donors demonstrate interest in investing in SHPs

target.comment: (B) US$ 3.2 mln leveraged for SHP construction

actual.comment: B) Norwegian bank NORFUND is interested to finance Haitian firms for two pilot plants. The IADB is willing to facilitate the Haitian Government to find the necessary guarantee funds.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) SHP Project Pipeline

baseline.comment: (C) Outdated and unreliable project pipeline;

target.comment: (C) Updated project pipeline; at least 8 new SHPs under consideration for development;

actual.comment: C) Work is in progress with the engineering firm LGL/ Genie Conseils and will be available soon.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: (D) SHP Policy Framework

baseline.comment: (D) No appropriate energy policy framework

target.comment: (D) Energy regulation in place, including support for SHP development.

actual.comment: D) Despite the delay in recruitment, the procedure will be restarted in order to define the scope of the regulation.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: An effective, market-oriented policy and regulatory framework to enable small hydropower development in the country has been established.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) Methodology to define reference cost and tariff SHP approved;

baseline.comment: (A) No SHP reference cost and tariff defined;

target.comment: (A) SHP reference cost and tariff defined;

actual.comment: A) The International Consultant Z. Contreras defined the reference methodology for calculating SHP tariff.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Proposal approved legal/commercial status of SHP operator;

baseline.comment: (B) No proposal SHP approved;

target.comment: (B) Proposal status SHP operator approved;

actual.comment: B) PPA under discussion (EDH, MTPTEC, Finance), awaiting signature

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) Resolutions approved defining (i) quality of service; (ii) land tenure, (iii) water rights and environmental issues.

baseline.comment: (C) No resolutions (a) drafted nor (b) approved.

target.comment: (C) Resolutions (a) drafted and (b) approved.

actual.comment: C) Not yet undertaken.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Technical and managerial capacities within EdH and other national stakeholders have been created to evaluate, prepare and operate small hydropower developments in Haiti.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) Measuring equipment procured and installed;

baseline.comment: (A) No measuring equipment identified;

target.comment: (A) Measuring equipment procured and installed;

actual.comment: A) Work is in progress and will end in October 15.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Mapping of relevant regions carried out;

baseline.comment: B) Data from 1979, no mapping using modern technologies

target.comment: (B) Mapping hydro potential relevant regions carried out;

actual.comment: B) Work done. See Joseph Constantin consultant report.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) Creation of SHP business unit in EdH;

baseline.comment: (C) No SHP business unit in EdH;

target.comment: (C) SHP business unit established;

actual.comment: C) The report of the international consultant, Mr.Fidel Montes Perez that is being finalized, will propose a structure for this Unit.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: (D) Internal capacities in EDH enhanced.

baseline.comment: (D) Low EdH Capacity for SHP management, no training material in place.

target.comment: (D) At least 30 EDH staff members are fully trained on SHP development, operation and maintenance; training material in place.

actual.comment: D) The report of the International Consultant Fidel Montes Perez being finalized will provide the profile and content of the relevant training.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: (E) Project Pipeline generated

baseline.comment: (E) No SHP project pipeline in place

target.comment: (E) At least 8 SHPs included in EDHâ€™s project pipeline and with preliminary financing agreements in place

actual.comment: E) Measuring devices to be installed will help in the development of future SHP network.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Small hydropower generation facilities are incorporated in regional distribution constructed and are providing electricity to end-users.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) Feasibility studies for SHP projects;

baseline.comment: (A) No feasibility studies;

target.comment: (A) 3 Feasibility studies completed;

actual.comment: A) The project has already made the environmental and social impact studies. Detailed studies for the realization of the signing of the PPA and will be made by the Company SOLEO.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Financing secured for SHPs

baseline.comment: (B) Private sector and donors demonstrate interest in investing in SHPs

target.comment: (B) Financing secured for construction of 3 SHPs

actual.comment: B) Process between Soleo (private operator) and Norfund (Norway Development Bank) to secure financing for the construction of 2 SHPs still awaiting PPA approval by the Haitian government

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) SHP plants procured and under construction;

baseline.comment: (C) No new SHP plants constructed in past 20 years;

target.comment: (C) 2 SHP plants in construction;

actual.comment: C) Implementation by the Company SOLEO subject to PPA approval by Haitian government.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: (D) Regional grids upgraded and fully operational

baseline.comment: (D) Jacmel grid restored, Les Cayes grid in poor conditions;

target.comment: (D) Jacmel and Les Cayes grids fully restored and SHP interconnection underway.

actual.comment: D) Target reached for the regional grid of les Cayes since last year.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: (E) Business plans for SHP operator.

baseline.comment: (E) No SHP business plans defined.

target.comment: (E) 3 business plans approved.

actual.comment: E) Not yet initiated

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: A project monitoring and evaluation plan implemented, and lessons learnt are disseminated.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: (A) Mid-term Evaluation Report;

baseline.comment: (A) No MTE;

target.comment: (A) MTE completed;

actual.comment: A) N/A (It is a small size project)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: (B) Final Evaluation Report;

baseline.comment: (B) No FEV;

target.comment: (B) FEV completed;

actual.comment: B) Not yet initiated

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: (C) Documentation of project Experiences;

baseline.comment: (C) No systematization of SHP experience in Haiti;

target.comment: (C) Lessons learnt publication;

actual.comment: C) The compilation is being done gradually

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: (D) Sharing of project results.

baseline.comment: (D) No sharing of SHP development experience in Haiti.

target.comment: (D) Seminar to present project results.

actual.comment: D) Decisions on project progress is shared with different stakeholders.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen adaptive capacities of populations and productive sectors in coastal areas to address increasing climate change risks

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of existing department to integrate climate change risks into departmental plans

baseline.comment: None of the current existing departments integrate climate risks into planning processes.

target.comment: Increase in current number by 100%.

actual.comment: 10 departments, through the Ministry of Environment, and the ministry of Interior ( as new partner) have done the exercise on climate change adaptation integration into local development planning. More in depth application training will be held at the end of September 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of related ministries, municipalities, CBOs and research institutions implementing climate change adaptation activities.

baseline.comment: None of the current set of (ministries, municipalities, CBOs and research institutions) implement cc-adaptation related activities.

target.comment: Increase the current number by 50% over established baseline at the beginning of the project.

actual.comment:
More in depth analysis of adaptation measures are being done with ministry of agriculture to be integrated in the farming plan strategy.
The ministry of tourism has taken into account the climate change threats in the development of a tourism project in the Southern region.
The ministry of Environment has prepared a draft planning document to facilitate the work initiated with the Ministry of Education related to the integration of CC basic knowledge in the Curricula (See attached document)
DINEPA, CNSA, ONEV, CNIGS, Private University, the Ministry of Finance, the Civil Protection Direction, The Civil Society, the State University and 15 municipalities continue to implement CC adaptation related activities.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Institutional capacity to plan for and respond to increasing coastal hazards improved

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Allocation of budget for CC adaptation targets in sectoral plans (Ministries, CIAT; SNGRD, CNSA, MARNDR)

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: 1. CIAT, MDE, MPCE, MARNDR; SNGRD; CNIGS, DINEPA; ONEV; CNSA all allocate budget lines to clearly defined adaptation targets

actual.comment:
Working with the direction of CC and all other sectorial ministries and relevant actors in the elaboration of the Intended National Determined Contribution - A Workshop on INDC elaboration methodologies has been organized for sectorial ministries staff in Port au prince with support from Organisation de la Francophonie.
Also, the technical and financial support to the direction of climate change has been reinforced through the EU-AP3C programme, and the in-kind contribution of the ministry of environment which is equivalent to 35k$
The report on COUNTRY CLIMATE PROFILE (intl Consultant) has been finalized and will be presented to the public at a workshop on August 20th.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage of vulnerable communes with published emergency evacuation plans adjusted to take into account increased climate risks

baseline.comment: 20 communes with EWS

target.comment: 20 communes with EWS adapted to increased climate risks and communal development plans with CC adaptation criteria

actual.comment:
Follow up on the workshop held in march. Specific workshop to be held with the representatives of the communes already working on integrating ACC in the communal development plan.
An additional workshop will be held in Desdunes, Artibonite with the local stakeholders and authorities on July 28-29-30 to work on integrating adaptation to CC measures into their local development planning
Study done on Strategic Environmental Assessment / vulnerability assessment regarding the management of inert solid waste in the coastal sites from the earthquake. (in collaboration with Relevement project-UNDP and MTPTC)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of local development plans integrating CC adaption strategies including assessment of investment needs as a result of training AND and capacity building conducted by the project

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: Key development institutions (CIAT, Primature, MARNDR; MDE;MPCE;MICT; MTPTC;MSPP; CNIGS; ONEV;CNSA) trained in adaptation to CC and with installed technical capacities capable of implementing adaptation actions according to NAPA

actual.comment:
3-day Training on Climate Explorer was organized for technical staff of MARNDR, MPCE,MTPTC, MSPP, CNIGS, ONEV, MDE, CNSA, Energy Office.
Technical trainings on Websmater and communication on climate change have been organized for the ministry of environment Staff and now the website on Climate change is being managed by the Ministry ( updates, and adds)
South South cooperation: Training sessions were organized in Costa Rica with CATIE for MDE, MARNDR staff on:
Gender and Climate Change - Mangroves restoration - Watershed management

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Climate Risks Management is fully mainstreamed into humanitarian and development investment frameworks

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Percentage of national investment frameworks incorporating adaptation to climate risks.

baseline.comment: Some NGOs are starting to incorporate CC adaptation within donor financed investment plans

target.comment: 1) 50% of the programmes funded through the interim commission for the reconstruction of Haiti include adaptation to CC targets and clear budget allocations

actual.comment:
1. Report on CC Adaptation costs in collaboration with the Finances Ministry is scheduled for presentation to the public, by August 20th.
2. Ongoing successful exchange meetings are being held with ministry of Tourism and IADB regarding an important Ecotourism project in the Southern region for which the experiences and achievement of the adaptation project are being considered for replication.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Percentage of humanitarian and development organizations with adaptation targets and budget lines

baseline.comment: None of the national policy and investment frameworks (post disaster recovery plan, national plans for poverty reduction etc..) include adaptation to CC targets

target.comment:
2) 60% of the donor organizations operating in Haiti have included adaptation to CC in coastal areas as a priority of their investment
3) 100% of the national development policies and plans have budget allocated to address clear adaptation to CC targets in coastal areas

actual.comment:
Exchange meetings with FAO on their review of the National Adaptation Plan Action in order to share the project best practices on the field.
Working with MPCE for ACC integration as a priority in their planning in collaboration with the project AP3C/EU and the CC Division
Ongoing discussion with the current director of climate change on the importance of developing the National Climate Change Policy.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Resilience of low-elevation coastal zones to emerging climate change threats enhanced.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % increase in awareness and response capacity to climate change and its impacts, particularly on the water and agriculture, sectors by the communities in pilot areas

baseline.comment: 1. Current field programs efforts remain largely dispersed with very little consideration paid to the new patterns of risk brought about by climate variability and change

target.comment: 1. 100% increase in the outreach and sensitization activities in all the communes in the pilot areas

actual.comment:
Ongoing preparation of a guidelines for replication and up-scaling of good practices from the pilot project in the South East (drinking water distribution systems management)
Second phase of water storage and distribution project with DINEPA to enhance capacities for economic valuation of the investment and maintenance of the water distribution system. 3 CAEPA will be reinforced during a 6 months time frame.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2 # of technologies for water, agriculture and food security sectors transferred to targeted areas.

baseline.comment: 2. No information available on the effect of CC on the water sector in coastal areas and no mitigation plans available

target.comment: 2. Investments needs identified to climate proof the water sector in the southern departments and relevant adaptation technology in targeted areas installed

actual.comment:
CNIGS is working with ONEV on the installation of 3 additional hydro climatic stations and further progress with SNRE/MARNDR to establish a climatic observation network for the Southern Department. This initiative is in collaboration with the project Hydromet of PPCR/CIAT-SNRE-MARNDR.
An important partnership is ongoing with Small Grant Programm on the Mangroves programme with a CBA approach. Village planet is providing training to technicians in the ministry of environment to improve their capacities in mangroves reforestation
TOR for a manual capitalizing on the good practices related to water resources and food security management techniques tested in the project, is ready for publication.
Climate Change Awareness programme are ongoing in the project sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Strengthening of capacities to address climate risk and food security within coastal rural livelihood y strategies in targeted areas indicated by # of people engaged in resilient livelihood activities;

baseline.comment: 3. No information available on the effect of CC on rural livelihoods in vulnerable watersheds and no mitigation plans available

target.comment: 3. Investment needs identified to climate proof rural livelihoods in targeted vulnerable watersheds and efficient monitoring system in place to guide adapted transfer of technology in targeted areas

actual.comment:
In the Southern region, the project is working with 5 more watershed committees to elaborate the Mangroves management plan.
Thanks to resources provided by the project, the MARNDR is working with 15 groups of farmers on women’s ownership of livestock and other income-generating activities. There will also be construction of water storage, post-harvest storage and food transformation facilities as climate change adaptation strategies.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Models of best practices and lessons learned from the project activities captured and institutionalized

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Number of ‘lessons learned’ systematized about managing climate change risks in coastal areas

baseline.comment: 1. There is very little available information on the adaptive capacities of populations and productive sectors in coastal areas (the baseline will be determined at the inception phase).

target.comment: 1. existence of knowledge forums and networks on adaptation to CC by the end of the project

actual.comment:
The climate change training kit is translated into Creole and available at central level via DEPREDD and, at local level, in 9 departments, via the MDE local offices
Experiences in the Southern region shared via ALM, and CCAF plateforms, and the CC website
The TORs are finalized for a consultancy on lessons learned and best practices report to be launched by end of 2015

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number of men and women (public and decision makers) having access to best practices and lessons learned from project activities.

baseline.comment: 2. Gender related data are currently not available. The baseline will be determined at the inception phase.

target.comment: 2. By the end of the project, at least “30”% of the women have access to best practices and lessons learned from the project in targeted areas over baseline established during the start up phase of the project.

actual.comment:
The consultancy on Gender analysis and gender strategy is ongoing.
Documentation on gender is translated into Creole (Cf. attached documents). Training on gender with the local partners is planned during the consultancy.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Number of ‘lessons learned’ disseminated through the ALM platform and other regional networks.

baseline.comment: 3. The baseline will be determined at the inception phase.

target.comment: 3. By the end of the project, project lessons are distributed in hard copy (e.g. pamphlets, briefing notes, newsletters, booklets, etc), electronically (e.g. via the project database), and via national and local workshops.

actual.comment: All the materials are disseminated in hard copy (CC training manual, 4 pamphlets, educational banner, 4 newsletters, success stories, photostories) and soft copy on ALM and the CC website

location.name: Port-au-Prince
location.activity-description: Les conditions requises en termes de matériels, liste électorale, personnel, formation technique des cadres et l’égalité des sexes sont réunis afin d’appuyer le Conseil Électoral Permanent dans la réalisation des élections.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Dans quelle mesure l’appui technique et opérationnel est fourni au CEP pour assurer le bon déroulement de toutes les étapes du processus électoral notamment la disponibilité de matériels sensibles et non-sensibles, la publication de la liste électorale 30 jours avant le jour de vote, l’exécution de la liste de paie, la disponibilité des résultats électoraux au CTV, l’exécution de la campagne de sensibilisation et d’éducation civique et la promotion de la participation des jeunes et des femmes.

baseline.comment: Besoin du renforcement de la structure organisationnelle du CEP pour assurer le bon déroulement des opérations électorales.

target.comment: De manière plus que satisfaisante, l’appui technique et opérationnel sont fourni au CEP pour assurer le bon déroulement de toutes les étapes du processus électoral selon le calendrier électoral grâce à la disponibilité de matériels sensibles et non-sensibles ; l’impression et vulgarisation de la liste électorale, l’exécution du paiement du personnel électorale temporaire, la disponibilité des résultats préliminaires, la mise en œuvre de la campagne de sensibilisation et d’éducation civique et la promotion de la participation des jeunes et des femmes.

actual.comment: De manière plus que satisfaisante, l’appui technique et opérationnel sont fourni au CEP qui a pu assurer le bon déroulement de toutes les étapes du processus électoral selon le calendrier électoral y compris le premier tour des législatives du 9 aout 2015 et le premier tour des présidentielles, des élections législatives partielles et des élections municipaux du 25 octobre 2015. Cela a été assuré grâce à la disponibilité de matériels sensibles et non-sensibles, l’impression et la publication de la liste électorale, l’exécution du paiement du personnel électorale temporaire, la disponibilité des résultats électoraux au CTV, la mise en œuvre de la campagne de sensibilisation et d’éducation civique et la promotion de la participation des jeunes et des femmes.

location.name: Port-au-Prince
location.activity-description: L’Office Nationale d’Identification (ONI) est renforcée pour assurer le déploiement efficace des unités mobiles et assurer l’impression et la distribution des cartes.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Dans quelle mesure les capacités de l’Office National d’Identification (ONI) sont renforcées avec des matériels nécessaires pour la production du nombre de Carte d’Identification Nationale (CIN) requises et la livraison des CIN de bonne qualité permettant la transmission efficace et précise des données au CEP pour alimenter les listes électorales.

baseline.comment: Capacité non adéquate de l’ONI pour transmettre des donnés au CEP pour les listes électorales et pour répondre aux demandes d’émission des nouvelles Cartes d’Identification National (CIN) en période électorale.

target.comment: De manière plus que satisfaisante, les capacités de l’Office National d’Identification sont renforcées avec des matériels et ressources nécessaires pour la livraison de 200,000 CIN de bonne qualité rendant l’institution capable de transmettre des données au CEP pour alimenter les listes électorales de façon efficace et précise.

actual.comment: De manière plus que satisfaisante, les capacités de l’Office National d’Identification sont renforcées avec des matériels et ressources nécessaires pour la production de 288,000 CIN et la livraison de 105,500 CIN de bonne qualité rendant l’institution capable de transmettre des données au CEP pour alimenter les listes électorales de façon efficace et précise.
